title: Will Hillary Clinton win New Hampshire's Democratic primary?
preds: Given her extensive history as a politician, Hillary does indeed stand a decent chance in winning the Democratic primary. She primarily appeals to women voters and is very popular among democrats. However, Hillary has received continuous backlash with her past statements and actions as well as her current standing under the Benghazi issue. Sanders is accumulating votes left and right for his strong integrity as well as appeal to the younger generation. All in all Sanders should be favored over Clinton.
Vermont is next to New Hampshire and the voters are very similar.

Clip from ABC News article:
'DEM CONTEST:
Honesty and trustworthiness is the most important candidate attribute, selected by more than three in 10 voters in preliminary exit poll results. Next are “someone who cares about people like me” and experience, at just more than a quarter each. Only about one in 10 are choosing “electability” as the top attribute. In Iowa, Sanders won with honesty and empathy voters, Clinton on experience and electability.
Far more New Hampshire voters see Sanders as honest and trustworthy than Clinton, and they feel he shares their values more so than she does.
Nearly seven in 10 voters in the Democratic primary describe themselves as liberals, including a quarter who say they’re very liberal, both up from 2008, when 56 percent identified as liberal and 20 percent said they were very liberal. If they hold, those would be new highs in exit polls back to 1980.'

@ts2m has been very helpful in returning me to the fold at the last minute.  The charts didn't show Concord, which is usually also a high-turnout party-regular burg as are Nashua and Manchester.  If you win big in those towns, every college student and professor in New Hampshire cannot help your opponent.  Also true that in the larger towns, it is much easier to get people to the polls, just because you don't have to drive twenty miles through the snow to get to the house of one voter.  Clinton has the money and staff to organize This Sort of Thing, so I've gone back to betting against the polls.
I'm sticking with the latest polls.  Though, Sanders has a 16 point lead the latest polls show he is dropping and Clinton is rising.

I'm downgrading my original forecast based on continually strong polling for Sanders. Again, the demographics of this make no sense. If anything Clinton and Sanders SHOULD be polling close based on the Iowa entrance polls and 2008 New Hampshire exit polls breakdown of voter attitudes toward their political orientation (very liberal, somewhat liberal, moderate, etc.). Historically, NH has almost always voted for the moderate candidate as well, with the exception of Paul Tsongas in 1992. Given that Tsongas was from Massachusetts, it may simply be the regional unity of New England trumps the politics of any given candidate. Certainly, there is a lot of evidence that New England bucks political identity - one need only look at Sanders own election as an independent socialist as well as the litany of interesting candidates out of Maine including Susan Collins, Olympia Snowe and Paul LePage that don't fit the national party's mold. I'll downgrade Clinton's changes for that reason, but if there's any sign of upward movement, I may upgrade her yet.
